Award.AwardTitle: Fluid-mobile and volatile element (Cl, B, and Li) cycling through the forearc: Case study of cold and thermal spring geochemistries from the Hikurangi accretionary prism, New Zeala
Award.AbstractNarration:
A subduction zone is an area where two tectonic plates collide and the denser plate (also called a subducting slab, consisting of seafloor sediments, oceanic crust, and underlying mantle) is forced to sink into the mantle beneath the more buoyant plate. Hydrous minerals in the slab break down when exposed to the high temperatures encountered at depth, releasing fluids ultimately involved in the creation of arc magmas and explosive arc volcanoes. In addition, these fluids are also thought to influence seismic slip behavior and the manifestation of earthquakes. Therefore, determining the sources and amount of fluids released at depth within a subduction is critical for understanding volcanic and earthquake behavior along plate margins.

Particular elements (for example, lithium, chlorine, and boron) are highly fluid-mobile, thereby making them excellent tracers of fluid source. These fluids impart diagnostic geochemical signatures to overlying material that can be used to trace mass transfer through subduction zones. This work will geochemically characterize cold and thermal spring waters from the Hikurangi (New Zealand subduction zone) accretionary prism to trace fluid sources along the fore-arc and quantify volatile flux through the fore-arc. Fluid sources to the fore-arc will be determined by examining variations in elemental concentrations (and ratios) and isotopic compositions. The data will be used to evaluate causal links between fluid sources and earthquake mechanics, such as shallow slow slip events. The Hikurangi margin is the ideal locality for this study due to the numerous exposed fore-arc springs, which allow a rare glimpse into the shallow part of the subduction zone, and the previously documented along arc variability in subduction parameters (e.g., amount of subducting sediment) and seismic slip behavior. Geochemical evidence for increased (or more shallow) dehydration reactions in the northern portion of the margin compared to the southern portion would support a link between dehydration reactions and shallow slow slip events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A subduction zone is an area where two tectonic plates collide and the denser plate (also called a subducting slab, consisting of seafloor sediments, oceanic crust, and underlying mantle) is forced to sink into the mantle beneath the more buoyant plate. Hydrous minerals in the slab break down when exposed to the high temperatures encountered at depth, releasing fluids ultimately involved in the creation of arc magmas and explosive arc volcanoes. In addition, these fluids are also thought to influence seismic slip behavior and the manifestation of earthquakes. Therefore, determining the sources and amount of fluids released at depth within a subduction is critical for understanding volcanic and earthquake behavior along plate margins.

Particular elements (such as lithium, chlorine, and boron) are highly fluid-mobile, thereby making them excellent tracers of fluid source. These fluids impart diagnostic geochemical signatures to overlying material that can be used to trace mass transfer through subduction zones. This work geochemically characterized cold and thermal spring waters from the Hikurangi margin (New Zealand subduction zone) to trace fluid sources and quantify volatile flux above the shallow part of the subduction zone. The Hikurangi margin is the ideal locality for this study due to the numerous exposed forearc springs, which are rarely exposed on land above the shallow part of the subduction zone. The geochemistry of the spring fluids were determined by examining variations in elemental concentrations (and ratios) and isotopic compositions, and allowed for the identification of different fluid sources to the spring waters. Previous work has documented variability in seismic behavior along the margin from slow slip events in the north to larger stick-slip earthquakes in the south. We hypothesized that the variation in seismic behavior may be a function of changing fluid sources from dehydration reactions in the subducting slab. This work shows that along the Hikurangi margin the fluids contain decreasing concentrations of chlorine, bromine, iodine, strontium, boron, lithium and sodium from north to south. Although the concentrations change, the elemental ratios and isotopic data show that the fluids are dominated by seawater and sedimentary pore fluids, with no change in fluid source along the margin. Instead, the observed geochemical trends along the margin reflect a change in the upper plate structural permeability, likely resulting from an extensional (and thus more highly permeable) margin in the north to transpression in the south trapping fluids within the upper plate and diluting saline fluids with groundwater. Such changes in upper plate structural permeability may influence fluid pressure conditions within the upper plate, which in turn may influence the observed change in slip behavior along the margin.

In addition, in order to interpret natural spring data, one needs to tease out the effect of local fluid-rock interaction. At elevated temperatures, elements and isotopes can partition between the fluid and the rock. This interaction can mask a deeper source signal and instead record a local process. Hydrothermal experimental work was conducted at conditions similar to those in continental hydrothermal systems (e.g., the Yellowstone hydrothermal system and the Taupo volcanic field). Water-rhyolite experiments were conducted over a temperature range of 150°C-350°C to constrain elemental leaching behaviors at each temperature, the secondary minerals formed, and how the secondary minerals control the concentrations of certain essential proxy fluid-mobile trace elements (Cl, F, Br, Li, and B). The experiments show the rhyolite is stable at temperatures ≤ 250°C. At T ≥ 275 °C, the rhyolite is completely broken down and recrystallized to a secondary mineral called zeolite. Fluorine has affinity for the zeolite and is removed from solution into this phase, whereas Cl and B are completely leached from the rock and remain in solution. Li is moderately fluid mobile over the entire temperature range. This suggests that zeolite may potentially be a major F sink in natural caldera-hosted, rhyolitic hydrothermal systems. The results also show that Cl and B isotopes to not fractionate significantly at T<350°C and there is only minor fractionation of Li isotopes in continental-hosted rhyolitic systems, suggesting that Cl, B, and Li isotopes are not effective geothermometers to be used in hydrothermal energy exploration.
